awd_titl_txt: Prediction and Mitigation of Beach Overwash and Resultant Urban Flooding in Coastal California
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will involve field studies and modeling to improve the prediction of wave-driven flooding at the scale of land parcels in urban areas. Recent research has shown that parcel-scale flood prediction is possible with modern data (e.g., lidar) and modeling resources, but urban coastlines remain a major challenge due to complex infrastructure and the difficulties posed by wave-driven flooding. A promising class of debris flow models will be applied to simulate swash zone dynamics and quantify sea wall and beach dune overtopping rates, critical forcing data for urban flooding models. We will also deploy wave gages and a terrestrial lidar system to monitor the erosion of protective sand berms that are constructed before winter storms. We seek an improved understanding of berm performance that can be used to improve emergency preparedness as well as the reliability of short-term coastal flooding forecasts. 

Trends of higher sea level, increased storm activity, and urbanization all point to a growing risk of coastal flood damage and the combination of these trends raises the possibility of a major disaster in developed coastal lowlands of California. A study by the USGS suggests that an atmospheric river event lasting several weeks is capable of $725 billion in flood losses across the State, several times the expected losses from a major southern California earthquake of the same probability. To plan a sustainable future, coastal communities need to examine many different adaptation measures in search of a mix that balances the economic, environmental and social priorities of the region. In addition, coastal communities need reliable flood forecasting systems to minimize losses during extreme events. This work will advance a fundamental understanding of processes, data and models that is needed to address these needs in southern California. These advances will position engineers and coastal managers to build more resilient communities for the present, and plan more sustainable coastal communities for the future. Moreover, a detailed investigation at Newport Beach offers the potential for a coastal adaptation paradigm that benefits communities across the Nation and beyond.

por.por_cntn:
This project was motivated by the growing danger of coastal flooding as a consequence of higher sea levels, which will make it easier for storm waves to erode and overtopping beaches that protect low lying coastal communities from flooding.

This project focused attention on the use and performance of temporary beach berms constructed with heavy equipment, which we term anthropogenic berms. This practice is used throughout the world to provide coastal communities extra flood protection during storm events, yet little is known about berm durability, and coastal flood prediction systems presently have no way of accounting for the effects of these berms on flood forecasts. 

In this project, we partnered with the City of Newport Beach in southern California to construct a prototype berm on three occasions in the Winter of 2012. The berms were constructed low on the foreshore of the beach where it was sure to contacted by waves with the rising tide, and we used a laser scanning device to measure how the shape of the berm changed over time as it was eroded. We also measured the waves directly offshore of the berm using a wave gage that was mounted on the ocean floor, so we could correlate the wave activity with berm erosion. These data allowed us to qualitatitively characterize the mechanisms by which berms were eroded, and to develop mechanistic computer models of berm erosion that can be used to predict berm erosion in the future. The computer model that we developed used innovative numerical methods that were originally developed to model debris flows, i.e., flows of fluid/solid mixtures, and our results indicate a high potential to benefit practical forecasting applications. In the future, we envision localized flooding forecasts with our model to support emergency decision-making by residents, business owners, community groups, and government officials. Early warning of the location, depth and timing of flood water is invaluable to minimize losses and business interruption.

Intellectual Merit

We obtained primary data on the durability of anthropogenic berms was exposed to waves, and developed an empirical model of berm erosion by analying laser scanning data and time lapse photography of berm erosion. These findings were published in a research article entitled "Terrestrial laser scanning of anthropogenic beach berm erosion" which was published by the Journal of Coastal Research in 2014.

We developed an innovative computer model to simulate the erosion of beach berms and the runup and overtopping of waves simultaneously. The model offers the ability to make localized predictions of coastal flooding when key ascillary data such as offshore wave conditions and beach and foreshore profile data are available. The numerical methods in the computer model were published in a research article entitled "The LHLLC Scheme for two-layer and two-phase transcritical flows" which was published by Advances in Water Resources in 2014, and the configuration of the model for coastal erosion and overtopping modeling is presented in a research article under preparation which is presently titled "Multi-Phase Shock-Capturing Model of Beach Hydromorphodynamics."

Southern California one of the most sensitive areas in the Nation with respect to changing flood risk as a result of sea level rise. Today's 100 year storm event will become an annual occurrence by 2050, which leaves communities only about 2-3 decades to plan and implement interventions that promote less damage and greater resilience. This project is raising awareness about coastal flood risk in the region and has created an opportunity for experts to dialogue with the community about the growing hazard as well as possible interventions.
